title: Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
text:
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
Economics student at McMaster University
Focused on the interplay between human-capital ecosystems, strategic resource allocation, and the security dimensions of global markets.
I study how innovation asymmetries and frictions amplify systemic risks, influence adversarial statecraft, and reshape power dynamics between nations. I aim to uncover vulnerabilities and leverage points within interconnected systems.
Career focus: National security, economic resilience, and strategic competition.

title: Strategic Frictions and Systemic Risk
text: Policy frictions are rarely isolated. In tightly coupled economies, small distortions can propagate through production networks, magnify uncertainty, and alter the strategic calculus of states and firms. My interest is in identifying which nodes and linkages act as accelerants, and where targeted intervention can dampen systemic risk without imposing persistent misallocation.

title: Research
text:
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
I develop and solve a dynamic general equilibrium model with capital accumulation and heterogeneous energy technologies to characterize the welfare-maximizing carbon tax path. The model highlights how investment responses and energy substitution jointly shape optimal policy and transition dynamics.
